description: The original meaning was 'sundial' and/or 'clock dial'; from Middle English diall, from Middle French dyal, from Latin diālis (“daily, concerning the day”), because of its use in telling the time of day, from Latin diēs (“day”). Compare Spanish dial and día (“day”).

entries.meaning: A graduated, circular scale over which a needle moves to show a measurement (such as speed).
examples: The dial on the dashboard showed the car was nearly out of gas.

entries.meaning: A panel on a radio etc showing wavelengths or channels; a knob that is turned to change the wavelength etc.
examples: Turn the dial to Radio 4: my favourite show is on!

entries.meaning: A disk with finger holes on a telephone; used to select the number to be called.
examples: His hands were too fat to operate the dial on the telephone.

entries.meaning: (UK, Australia, slang) A person's face. [from 19th c.]
examples: Old Mona Lisa would have looked like a sour lemon beside Angel Day on the rare days she put a smile on her dial, laughing with her friends when some new man was in town.

verbs.description: dial (third-person singular simple present dials, present participle (US) dialing or dialling, simple past and past participle (US) dialed or dialled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To control or select something with a dial, or (figuratively) as if with a dial.
examples: The president has recently dialled down the rhetoric.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To select a number, or to call someone, on a telephone.
(intransitive) To use a dial or a telephone.
